questions.question_text: How is sound produced?

options.label: C
options.text: By the vibrations of a body.

options.label: D
options.text: By applying pressure on an object.

questions.key_concept: Sound is produced by a vibrating body.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a source of sound?
questions.key_concept: A vibrating body is a source of sound.

questions.question_text: When a stretched rubber string is plucked, sound is heard. If the string is made to vibrate in a vacuum, what will happen?

options.label: A
options.text: Sound will be louder because there is no air resistance.

options.label: B
options.text: Sound will not be heard because a medium is required for sound propagation.

options.label: C
options.text: Sound will have a higher pitch.

options.label: D
options.text: The string will not vibrate at all in a vacuum.

questions.key_concept: Sound production requires a vibrating body, but propagation requires a material medium. In vacuum, sound cannot travel to the ear.

questions.question_text: In an experiment, a paper rider is placed on a stretched wire. When the wire is plucked, the rider flies off. What does this demonstrate?

options.label: B
options.text: The wire vibrates and produces sound.

questions.key_concept: The flying off of the rider shows the wire is vibrating, which is the cause of sound production.

questions.question_text: How does the production of sound differ from the production of light?

options.label: A
options.text: Both require a medium for production.

options.label: B
options.text: Sound requires a vibrating body; light does not require a vibrating source.

options.label: C
options.text: Light requires a vibrating body; sound does not.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither requires a source for production.

questions.key_concept: Sound is produced by mechanical vibrations of a body. Light is produced by electronic transitions or other processes, not necessarily by vibrations.

questions.question_text: Why does sound cease when a vibrating tuning fork is touched with a hand?

options.label: A
options.text: The hand absorbs the sound waves.

options.label: B
options.text: The hand increases the frequency of vibration.

options.label: C
options.text: The hand dampens the vibrations, stopping the source of sound.

options.label: D
options.text: The hand reflects the sound waves away.

questions.key_concept: Sound is produced by vibrations. Touching the fork stops the vibrations, thus stopping sound production.

questions.question_text: What is necessary for the propagation of sound from one place to another?
questions.key_concept: A material medium is necessary for the propagation of sound.

questions.question_text: In which of the following can sound NOT travel?
questions.key_concept: Sound cannot travel through vacuum as it requires a material medium.

questions.question_text: In the bell jar experiment, when air is removed, the sound of the electric bell becomes fainter and eventually inaudible. What does this prove?

options.label: A
options.text: The bell stops vibrating in a vacuum.

options.label: B
options.text: Sound requires a medium for propagation; in vacuum, it cannot travel.

options.label: D
options.text: The observer's ears stop working in vacuum.

questions.key_concept: The experiment demonstrates that sound needs a material medium. The bell still vibrates (seen) but sound is not heard because the medium (air) is removed.

questions.question_text: Why can two astronauts on the moon's surface not hear each other directly?

options.label: B
options.text: Because the moon has no atmosphere (medium) for sound to travel.

options.label: C
options.text: Because sound travels too fast on the moon.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the moon's gravity is too low.

questions.key_concept: The moon has no atmosphere (a material medium), so sound cannot propagate.

questions.question_text: How does the requirement of a medium for sound differ from that for light?

options.label: A
options.text: Both sound and light require a material medium.

options.label: B
options.text: Sound requires a material medium; light can travel through vacuum.

options.label: C
options.text: Light requires a material medium; sound can travel through vacuum.

questions.key_concept: Sound is a mechanical wave requiring a medium. Light is an electromagnetic wave and can travel through vacuum.

questions.question_text: Why are thick curtains used in studios to reduce sound?

options.label: B
options.text: They absorb sound energy, reducing its propagation through the medium (air).

options.label: C
options.text: They increase the speed of sound.

questions.key_concept: Porous materials like curtains absorb sound energy, dampening the vibrations in the medium and reducing propagation.

questions.question_text: In which form does sound travel through air?
questions.key_concept: Sound travels in air as a longitudinal wave.

questions.question_text: What are the regions of high pressure and low pressure in a longitudinal sound wave called?
questions.key_concept: In a longitudinal wave, compression (high pressure) and rarefaction (low pressure) are formed.

questions.question_text: As a longitudinal sound wave propagates, the particles of the medium:

options.label: A
options.text: Travel along with the wave from the source to the listener.

options.label: B
options.text: Vibrate about their mean positions in the direction of wave propagation.

options.label: C
options.text: Vibrate perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation.

questions.key_concept: In a longitudinal wave, particles oscillate back and forth along the direction of propagation, not travel with the wave.

questions.question_text: When a vibrating tuning fork is placed with its stem on a table, the sound becomes louder. This is because:

options.label: B
options.text: The table provides a larger surface area to set more air particles into longitudinal vibration.

questions.key_concept: The table acts as a larger vibrating surface, forcing more air particles to oscillate longitudinally, increasing the intensity.

questions.question_text: How does a longitudinal wave differ from a transverse wave?

options.label: A
options.text: Longitudinal waves can travel in vacuum; transverse cannot.

options.label: B
options.text: In longitudinal waves, particle vibration is parallel to wave direction; in transverse, it is perpendicular.

options.label: C
options.text: Longitudinal waves have crests and troughs; transverse have compressions and rarefactions.

options.label: D
options.text: Transverse waves can only travel in gases.

questions.key_concept: The fundamental difference is the direction of particle vibration relative to wave propagation.

questions.question_text: Why are sound waves classified as mechanical longitudinal waves?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are produced by machines.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they require a material medium (mechanical) and involve particle vibrations parallel to propagation (longitudinal).

options.label: C
options.text: Because they travel at the speed of light.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are electromagnetic in nature.

questions.key_concept: "Mechanical" indicates need for a medium. "Longitudinal" describes the nature of particle oscillation.

questions.question_text: What is a transverse wave?

options.label: A
options.text: A wave where particles vibrate parallel to the wave direction.

options.label: B
options.text: A wave where particles vibrate perpendicular to the wave direction.

options.label: C
options.text: A wave that can only travel in gases.

options.label: D
options.text: A wave that does not transfer energy.

questions.key_concept: In a transverse wave, particles vibrate perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a transverse wave?
questions.key_concept: Waves on strings or water surfaces are transverse. Sound in fluids is longitudinal.

questions.question_text: Can transverse waves be produced inside a gas like air?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because gases can support shearing stress.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because gases cannot sustain shearing stress; they only support longitudinal waves.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only at very high frequencies.

options.label: D
options.text: No, but light is a transverse wave in air.

questions.key_concept: Transverse waves require a restoring force due to shear stress, which gases lack. Light is electromagnetic, not mechanical.

questions.question_text: When a stone is dropped in a pond, a cork on the surface bobs up and down but does not move towards the shore. This illustrates:

options.label: C
options.text: The wave is transverse, transferring energy outward while particles oscillate perpendicularly.

options.label: D
options.text: The water is not a good medium.

questions.key_concept: The cork's vertical motion shows particle vibration is perpendicular to the direction of wave travel (radially outward), characteristic of transverse waves on surfaces.

questions.question_text: In which media can transverse waves propagate?

options.label: B
options.text: In solids and on the surface of liquids

questions.key_concept: Transverse mechanical waves need a restoring force (elasticity). Solids support them throughout. Liquids support them only at surfaces due to surface tension. Gases do not.

questions.question_text: Why are light waves considered transverse while sound waves in air are not?

options.label: B
options.text: Because light is an electromagnetic wave with electric and magnetic fields oscillating perpendicular to direction; sound is a mechanical longitudinal wave.

options.label: C
options.text: Because light can travel in vacuum.

options.label: D
options.text: Because sound has compressions and rarefactions.

questions.key_concept: The classification is based on the nature of oscillation: light's field oscillations are transverse to propagation. Sound's pressure oscillations are longitudinal.

concepts.concept_name: Wave characteristics: Amplitude, Time Period, Frequency

questions.question_text: What is the amplitude of a wave?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of waves per second.

options.label: B
options.text: The time for one complete vibration.

options.label: C
options.text: The maximum displacement of a particle from its mean position.

options.label: D
options.text: The distance between two consecutive crests.

questions.key_concept: Amplitude is the maximum displacement of a vibrating particle from its mean position.

questions.question_text: Which unit is used for frequency?
questions.key_concept: The SI unit of frequency is hertz (Hz), which is equivalent to per second (s⁻¹).

questions.question_text: If the frequency of a source is 50 Hz, what is its time period?
questions.key_concept: Time period T = 1/f. So T = 1/50 = 0.02 s. A common mistake is to confuse reciprocal.

questions.question_text: The amplitude of a sound wave is doubled. How does this affect its loudness and pitch?

options.label: A
options.text: Loudness increases, pitch remains the same.

questions.key_concept: Amplitude determines loudness (energy). Frequency determines pitch. Doubling amplitude increases loudness, not pitch.

questions.question_text: How are frequency and time period related?
questions.key_concept: Frequency (f) = 1 / Time period (T). Hence, they are inversely proportional.

questions.question_text: Why does the frequency of a sound wave remain unchanged when it travels from air into water?

options.label: A
options.text: Because frequency depends on the source, not the medium.

options.label: B
options.text: Because water is denser than air.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the speed of sound changes.

questions.key_concept: Frequency is a characteristic of the source. When wave enters a new medium, speed and wavelength change, but frequency remains constant.

questions.question_text: What is the wavelength of a wave?

options.label: A
options.text: The speed at which the wave travels.

options.label: B
options.text: The distance between two consecutive points in the same phase (e.g., two compressions).

options.label: C
options.text: The height of the wave from the mean position.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of waves passing a point per second.

questions.key_concept: Wavelength (λ) is the distance between two consecutive points in the same phase of vibration.

questions.question_text: The wave velocity is defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: The velocity of a particle of the medium.

options.label: B
options.text: The distance travelled by the wave per unit time.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of waves per unit time.

options.label: D
options.text: The maximum velocity of a vibrating particle.

questions.key_concept: Wave velocity (V) is the speed at which the wave disturbance (energy) travels through the medium.

questions.question_text: If the frequency of a wave is doubled and its speed remains constant, what happens to its wavelength?
questions.key_concept: From V = fλ, if V constant, f ∝ 1/λ. Doubling f halves λ.

questions.question_text: A wave has a frequency of 100 Hz and a wavelength of 3.3 m. What is its speed?
questions.key_concept: V = fλ = 100 Hz * 3.3 m = 330 m/s. This is approximately the speed of sound in air.

questions.question_text: How does wavelength change when a sound wave goes from air to water? (Assume frequency constant)
questions.key_concept: V = fλ. Speed of sound is higher in water. For constant f, λ increases with V.

questions.question_text: Why is the relation V = fλ fundamental for wave motion?

options.label: A
options.text: It defines the unit of frequency.

options.label: B
options.text: It connects the wave's speed (a medium property) with its frequency (source property) and wavelength (medium property).

options.label: C
options.text: It is only true for light waves.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that speed depends on amplitude.

questions.key_concept: The equation V = fλ is a universal wave relation linking the three key wave characteristics.

concepts.concept_name: Speed of sound in different media

questions.question_text: In which medium does sound travel fastest?
questions.key_concept: Sound travels fastest in solids, then liquids, and slowest in gases.

questions.question_text: What is the approximate speed of sound in air at 0°C?
questions.key_concept: The speed of sound in air at 0°C is about 330 m/s.

questions.question_text: The speed of sound in a medium depends on:

options.label: A
options.text: Frequency and amplitude of the wave.

options.label: B
options.text: Elasticity and density of the medium.

options.label: C
options.text: Wavelength and frequency of the wave.

questions.key_concept: Speed of sound depends on the properties of the medium: elasticity (E) and density (ρ), given by V = √(E/ρ). It is independent of frequency and amplitude.

questions.question_text: A person hears two sounds when a long steel bar is struck at one end. Why?

options.label: A
options.text: Because sound reflects from the other end.

options.label: B
options.text: Because sound travels at different speeds in steel and air, reaching the ear at different times.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the ear detects two different frequencies.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the sound is produced twice.

questions.key_concept: Sound travels faster in steel (~5100 m/s) than in air (~330 m/s). The sound through steel arrives first, followed by the sound through air.

questions.question_text: Arrange the speed of sound in the following media in increasing order: Air, Water, Steel.
questions.key_concept: Typical speeds: Air (~330 m/s), Water (~1450 m/s), Steel (~5100 m/s).

questions.question_text: Why does sound travel faster in solids than in gases?

options.label: A
options.text: Because solids are hotter than gases.

options.label: B
options.text: Because particles in solids are closer, leading to higher elasticity (greater restoring force) which increases speed more than the increase in density.

options.label: D
options.text: Because sound waves are longitudinal in solids and transverse in gases.

questions.key_concept: Speed V = √(E/ρ). Solids have a much higher modulus of elasticity (E) compared to gases, which outweighs their higher density (ρ), resulting in a higher speed.

concepts.concept_name: Factors affecting speed of sound in a gas

questions.question_text: How does temperature affect the speed of sound in air?

options.label: A
options.text: Speed decreases with increase in temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: Speed increases with increase in temperature.

questions.key_concept: The speed of sound in air increases with temperature.

questions.question_text: In which condition does sound travel faster?
questions.key_concept: Sound travels faster in humid air because the density of moist air is less than dry air (V ∝ 1/√ρ).

questions.question_text: Does the speed of sound in air change with a change in atmospheric pressure (at constant temperature)?

options.label: C
options.text: No, it remains constant because the ratio P/ρ remains constant.

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes zero at very high pressure.

questions.key_concept: For an ideal gas, V = √(γP/ρ). At constant temperature, P/ρ is constant, so speed is independent of pressure.

questions.question_text: If the temperature rises from 0°C to 20°C, by how much does the speed of sound in air approximately increase? (Use 0.61 m/s per °C)
questions.key_concept: Increase = 0.61 m/s per °C * 20 °C = 12.2 m/s.

questions.question_text: Compare the speed of sound in hydrogen and oxygen at the same temperature and pressure.

options.label: A
options.text: Speed is greater in oxygen because it is heavier.

options.label: B
options.text: Speed is greater in hydrogen because its density is lower (V ∝ 1/√ρ).

options.label: C
options.text: Speed is the same in both.

options.label: D
options.text: Speed depends on the volume, not density.

questions.key_concept: V = √(γP/ρ). At same P and T, ρ(H2) < ρ(O2). Therefore, V(H2) > V(O2).

questions.question_text: Why does sound travel faster when the wind is blowing in the direction of sound?

options.label: A
options.text: Because wind increases the frequency of sound.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the net speed of sound relative to ground becomes (speed in still air + wind speed).

options.label: C
options.text: Because wind reduces the density of air.

options.label: D
options.text: Because wind carries the sound particles.

questions.key_concept: The speed of sound is relative to the medium. If the medium (air) itself moves with wind speed W in the sound direction, the ground-relative speed becomes V + W.

concepts.concept_name: Comparison of speed of sound and light

questions.question_text: What is the approximate speed of light in air/vacuum?
questions.key_concept: The speed of light in vacuum/air is about 3 x 10^8 m/s.

questions.question_text: Which travels faster in air?

options.label: C
options.text: Both travel at the same speed.

questions.key_concept: Light travels about a million times faster than sound in air.

questions.question_text: During a thunderstorm, we see lightning before hearing thunder because:

options.label: B
options.text: Light travels much faster than sound in air.

options.label: C
options.text: Our eyes react faster than our ears.

questions.key_concept: Light and sound are produced simultaneously. The large difference in their speeds causes the observed delay.

questions.question_text: A gun is fired at a distance. An observer sees the flash and hears the sound 2 seconds later. If the speed of sound is 340 m/s, what is the distance? (Assume light travel time is negligible)
questions.key_concept: Distance = speed of sound * time = 340 m/s * 2 s = 680 m. The approximation is that light travel time is zero.

questions.question_text: How does the speed of light change when going from air to water, compared to the speed of sound?
questions.key_concept: Light slows down in an optically denser medium (water). Sound speeds up in a denser medium (water compared to air).

questions.question_text: Why can we approximate the light travel time as zero in calculating distances using the sound delay method?

options.label: A
options.text: Because light doesn't travel in air.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the speed of light is so large that the distance covered in a few seconds is negligible compared to the distance sound travels.

options.label: C
options.text: Because our eyes ignore the light travel time.

options.label: D
options.text: Because light and sound start at different times.

questions.key_concept: For distances on Earth, light takes microseconds, while sound takes seconds. The error from ignoring light time is minuscule.

questions.question_text: What is the audible range of frequency for a healthy human ear?
questions.key_concept: The normal human audible range is approximately 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz.

questions.question_text: Sound of frequency 25 kHz is classified as:
questions.key_concept: Ultrasonic sound has frequency above 20 kHz.

questions.question_text: A seconds pendulum completes one oscillation in 2 seconds. Will the sound produced by its vibration be audible?

options.label: B
options.text: No, because its frequency (0.5 Hz) is infrasonic (<20 Hz).

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because its amplitude is large.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because it doesn't produce sound.

questions.key_concept: Frequency f = 1/T = 1/2 = 0.5 Hz, which is below the audible range (infrasonic).

questions.question_text: Which animal is known to use ultrasonic sound for navigation?
questions.key_concept: Bats produce and detect ultrasonic waves for echolocation.

questions.question_text: How does the audible range of a young child compare to that of an old person?

options.label: A
options.text: The child can hear higher frequencies than the old person.

options.label: B
options.text: The old person can hear higher frequencies.

options.label: D
options.text: The child can hear lower frequencies only.

questions.key_concept: Hearing sensitivity, especially to high frequencies, decreases with age.

questions.question_text: Why are ultrasonic waves used for cleaning delicate instruments instead of audible sound?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they carry more energy (due to high frequency) and have high directivity, allowing precise cleaning.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are inaudible and less disturbing.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they travel slower, giving more time for cleaning.

questions.key_concept: High frequency means high energy per wave. Directivity allows focused application. Audible sound lacks these properties for effective cleaning.
